description: Microsoft 365 Identity Security Controls with Simple and Technical Explanations - Part 1

controls.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Enforcement
controls.description: Verify that MFA is enforced for all users through Conditional Access policies
controls.pass_message: MFA Conditional Access policies are properly configured and enabled
controls.fail_message: No active MFA enforcement policies found - critical security gap
controls.remediation: Create Conditional Access policy requiring MFA for all users and applications

simple_explanation.what_was_checked: We checked if your organization requires all users to use multi-factor authentication (like a phone app or text message) when logging in.
simple_explanation.why_it_matters: Multi-factor authentication is one of the most effective ways to prevent account takeovers. Without it, stolen passwords can give attackers full access to your systems and data.

pass_explanation.what_was_found: Multi-factor authentication is properly required for users through security policies.
pass_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚úÖ Excellent! This critical security measure is working properly.
pass_explanation.user_impact: Users will have secure login processes that protect their accounts and company data.

fail_explanation.what_was_found: Multi-factor authentication is not required for all users - this is a significant security gap.
fail_explanation.plain_english_result: üö® Action Required! This is a critical security issue that needs immediate attention.
fail_explanation.risk_level: Very High Risk - Immediate Action Needed
fail_explanation.user_impact: Users' accounts are vulnerable to takeover if passwords are stolen. Company data could be accessed by unauthorized people.

error_explanation.what_was_found: We couldn't check this setting due to insufficient permissions or configuration issues.
error_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ùì We couldn't complete this check. This might be due to licensing or permission limitations.
error_explanation.user_impact: The impact on users depends on the actual MFA configuration, which we couldn't verify.

required_licenses: Azure AD Premium P1 (minimum)
Azure AD Premium P2 (recommended)
Microsoft 365 E3 or higher
Office 365 E3 with Azure AD Premium P1 add-on
required_permissions: Policy.Read.All - To read Conditional Access policies
Directory.Read.All - To read directory objects
Application.Read.All - For application-scoped policies
technical_explanation.technical_remediation:
1. Navigate to Azure AD Admin Center > Security > Conditional Access
2. Create new policy: 'Require MFA for All Users'
3. Assignments: Users/Groups = All users, Cloud apps = All cloud apps
4. Access controls: Grant = Require multi-factor authentication
5. Enable policy and test with pilot group first
6. Monitor policy effectiveness and user impact
7. Create exclusions for emergency access accounts
8. Document policy configuration and business justification
configuration_paths: Azure Portal > Azure Active Directory > Security > Conditional Access > Policies
Microsoft 365 Admin Center > Security > Conditional Access
Azure AD Admin Center > Protection > Conditional Access
PowerShell: Connect-AzureAD; Get-AzureADMSConditionalAccessPolicy
powershell_commands:
# Connect to Azure AD
Connect-AzureAD

# Get all Conditional Access policies
Get-AzureADMSConditionalAccessPolicy | Select-Object DisplayName, State, Id

# Get MFA-enabled policies
Get-AzureADMSConditionalAccessPolicy | Where-Object {$_.GrantControls.BuiltInControls -contains 'mfa'} | Select-Object DisplayName, State
technical_explanation.security_implications: Lack of MFA enforcement creates a single point of failure in authentication. Password-only authentication is vulnerable to credential stuffing, password spraying, phishing attacks, and social engineering.
technical_explanation.implementation_complexity: Medium - Requires careful planning for user rollout and comprehensive user training. Consider pilot deployment and gradual rollout strategy.
technical_explanation.estimated_time_to_remediate: 2-4 weeks for full deployment including planning, pilot testing, and gradual rollout with user communications and training

controls.name: Privileged User MFA Enforcement
controls.description: Verify that all privileged users have MFA enabled and enforced
controls.evaluation: $privilegedRoles = $data.value | Where-Object { $_.displayName -in @('Global Administrator', 'Privileged Role Administrator', 'Security Administrator', 'Conditional Access Administrator', 'Exchange Administrator') }; $totalPrivilegedUsers = ($privilegedRoles | ForEach-Object { $_.members }).Count; $totalPrivilegedUsers -gt 0
controls.pass_message: Privileged accounts are properly identified for MFA verification
controls.fail_message: Unable to verify privileged account MFA status
controls.remediation: Enable MFA for all privileged accounts and create specific CA policies

simple_explanation.what_was_checked: We checked if your administrators and other privileged users are required to use multi-factor authentication.
simple_explanation.why_it_matters: Administrative accounts have access to everything in your organization. If these accounts are compromised, attackers can steal data, install malware, or shut down your systems.

pass_explanation.what_was_found: Privileged users are identified and should have multi-factor authentication requirements.
pass_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚úÖ Good! Privileged accounts are properly identified for MFA enforcement.
pass_explanation.user_impact: Administrators will have secure login processes that protect critical company systems.

fail_explanation.what_was_found: We couldn't verify that privileged users have proper MFA requirements.
fail_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ö†Ô∏è Important! Privileged account protection needs verification.
fail_explanation.user_impact: Administrative accounts may be vulnerable to takeover, putting all company systems at risk.

error_explanation.what_was_found: We couldn't access privileged user information due to permission restrictions.
error_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ùì Unable to verify privileged account security.
error_explanation.user_impact: Cannot determine the security status of administrative accounts.

required_licenses: Azure AD Premium P1 (minimum for CA policies)
Azure AD Premium P2 (recommended for PIM and advanced features)
Microsoft 365 E5 (includes Azure AD Premium P2)
Enterprise Mobility + Security E5
required_permissions: RoleManagement.Read.Directory - To read directory role assignments
User.Read.All - To read user properties and MFA status
Policy.Read.All - To verify CA policies affecting privileged users
AuditLog.Read.All - To review privileged access audit logs
technical_explanation.technical_remediation:
1. Create dedicated CA policy for privileged users
2. Target: Directory roles (Global Admin, Security Admin, etc.)
3. Conditions: All cloud apps, any location, any device state
4. Controls: Require MFA + compliant device + approved client app
5. Consider implementing Azure AD PIM for just-in-time access
6. Set up emergency access (break-glass) accounts with different MFA methods
configuration_paths: Azure Portal > Azure AD > Roles and administrators
Azure Portal > Azure AD > Security > Conditional Access
Azure Portal > Azure AD > Privileged Identity Management
technical_explanation.security_implications: Privileged account compromise represents the highest risk scenario for organizations. These accounts are primary targets for advanced persistent threats (APTs) and nation-state actors.
technical_explanation.implementation_complexity: High - Requires careful coordination with administrative users and comprehensive testing of emergency access procedures.
technical_explanation.estimated_time_to_remediate: 1-2 weeks for basic CA policy implementation, 4-6 weeks for full PIM deployment with comprehensive training

controls.name: MFA Registration Campaign
controls.description: Verify MFA registration status across all users
controls.remediation: Launch MFA registration campaign and implement nudging policies

simple_explanation.what_was_checked: We checked how many of your users have set up multi-factor authentication on their accounts.
simple_explanation.why_it_matters: Even if MFA is required, users need to actually set it up on their devices. Low registration rates mean many accounts are still vulnerable.

pass_explanation.what_was_found: A good percentage of users have set up multi-factor authentication (95% or higher).
pass_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚úÖ Great! Most users have completed their MFA setup.
pass_explanation.user_impact: Most users are protected with secure login methods.

fail_explanation.what_was_found: Too few users have set up multi-factor authentication, leaving many accounts vulnerable.
fail_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ö†Ô∏è Important! More users need to complete their MFA setup.
fail_explanation.user_impact: Many users' accounts are at risk because they haven't set up multi-factor authentication.

error_explanation.what_was_found: We couldn't retrieve MFA registration statistics.
error_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ùì Unable to check MFA registration rates.
error_explanation.user_impact: Cannot determine how many users have completed MFA setup.

required_licenses: Azure AD Premium P1 (for detailed reporting and campaigns)
Office 365 E3 or higher
Microsoft 365 Business Premium or higher
required_permissions: Reports.Read.All - To access authentication method reports
AuditLog.Read.All - For detailed registration events and tracking
UserAuthenticationMethod.Read.All - For per-user method details
technical_explanation.technical_remediation:
1. Enable MFA registration enforcement in Azure AD Authentication Methods Policy
2. Configure registration nudging policies with appropriate grace periods
3. Set up combined security info registration experience
4. Deploy Microsoft Authenticator via Intune configuration policies
5. Create comprehensive user training materials and video tutorials
configuration_paths: Azure Portal > Azure AD > Security > Authentication methods > Activity
Azure Portal > Azure AD > Users > Authentication methods
powershell_commands:
# Get MFA registration details via Microsoft Graph
Connect-MgGraph -Scopes 'Reports.Read.All'
Get-MgReportCredentialUserRegistrationDetail | Select-Object UserPrincipalName, IsMfaRegistered, MethodsRegistered
technical_explanation.security_implications: Low MFA registration rates create significant security gaps even when MFA policies are technically enabled. Unregistered users represent the weakest links in the authentication chain.
technical_explanation.implementation_complexity: Medium - Requires comprehensive user communication strategy and help desk preparation.
technical_explanation.estimated_time_to_remediate: 4-8 weeks for full campaign including planning, communication strategy, and user registration period

controls.name: Legacy Authentication Blocking
controls.description: Verify that legacy authentication protocols are blocked
controls.fail_message: Legacy authentication not blocked - security vulnerability exists
controls.remediation: Create CA policy to block legacy authentication protocols

simple_explanation.what_was_checked: We checked if your organization blocks old, less secure ways of connecting to email and other services.
simple_explanation.why_it_matters: Old authentication methods have security flaws that can't support modern protections like multi-factor authentication. Attackers often exploit these weaknesses.

pass_explanation.what_was_found: Old authentication methods are blocked, preventing less secure connections.
pass_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚úÖ Excellent! Legacy authentication vulnerabilities are blocked.
pass_explanation.user_impact: Users must use modern, secure applications to access company services.

fail_explanation.what_was_found: Old, insecure authentication methods are still allowed, creating security risks.
fail_explanation.plain_english_result: üö® Critical! Old authentication methods create serious security vulnerabilities.
fail_explanation.risk_level: Very High Risk - Immediate Action Needed
fail_explanation.user_impact: Attackers could use old vulnerabilities to access email and other services without proper authentication.

error_explanation.what_was_found: We couldn't verify if legacy authentication is blocked.
error_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ùì Unable to check legacy authentication settings.
error_explanation.user_impact: Cannot determine if old authentication vulnerabilities are protected against.

required_licenses: Azure AD Premium P1 (minimum for Conditional Access)
Office 365 E3 or higher
Microsoft 365 Business Premium or higher
required_permissions: Policy.Read.All - To read Conditional Access policies
Policy.ReadWrite.ConditionalAccess - To create/modify blocking policies
affected_system_components: Exchange Online (POP3, IMAP4, SMTP Auth, ActiveSync)
Third-party email clients using basic authentication
technical_explanation.technical_remediation:
1. Inventory all applications using legacy authentication
2. Update or replace applications to support modern authentication
3. Create Conditional Access policy: 'Block Legacy Authentication'
4. Target: All users, Cloud apps: All cloud apps
5. Conditions: Client apps = Exchange ActiveSync, Other clients
6. Access controls: Block access
7. Enable policy in report-only mode first for impact assessment

related_documentation.title: Block legacy authentication with Conditional Access

configuration_paths: Azure Portal > Azure AD > Security > Conditional Access > New policy
technical_explanation.security_implications: Legacy authentication protocols fundamentally bypass modern security controls. These protocols are vulnerable to password spraying, credential stuffing, and man-in-the-middle attacks.
technical_explanation.implementation_complexity: High - Requires comprehensive application inventory and extensive user impact assessment.
technical_explanation.estimated_time_to_remediate: 6-12 weeks for comprehensive implementation including application discovery, updates, and phased policy deployment

controls.name: Passwordless Authentication Configuration
controls.description: Verify passwordless authentication methods are available and promoted
controls.remediation: Enable and configure FIDO2 and Windows Hello for Business

simple_explanation.what_was_checked: We checked if users can log in without passwords using modern security methods like fingerprints, face recognition, or security keys.
simple_explanation.why_it_matters: Passwordless authentication is more secure and convenient than passwords. It eliminates the risk of password theft while making login easier for users.

pass_explanation.what_was_found: Modern passwordless authentication methods are available for users.
pass_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚úÖ Great! Users can use secure, password-free login methods.
pass_explanation.user_impact: Users can log in securely using fingerprints, face recognition, or security keys instead of passwords.

fail_explanation.what_was_found: Passwordless authentication options are not available to users.
fail_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ö†Ô∏è Consider enabling passwordless authentication for better security and user experience.
fail_explanation.user_impact: Users must rely on passwords, which are less secure and convenient than modern alternatives.

error_explanation.what_was_found: We couldn't check passwordless authentication settings.
error_explanation.plain_english_result: ‚ùì Unable to verify passwordless authentication availability.
error_explanation.user_impact: Cannot determine what login options are available to users.

required_licenses: Azure AD Premium P1 (for FIDO2 security keys)
Azure AD Premium P2 (for advanced passwordless features)
Windows 10/11 Pro or Enterprise (for Windows Hello for Business)
required_permissions: Policy.Read.All - To read authentication methods policy
Policy.ReadWrite.AuthenticationMethod - To configure passwordless methods
technical_explanation.technical_remediation:
1. Enable FIDO2 security keys in Azure AD Authentication Methods Policy
2. Configure Windows Hello for Business via Group Policy or Intune
3. Enable Microsoft Authenticator passwordless phone sign-in
4. Set up device compliance requirements for passwordless methods
configuration_paths: Azure Portal > Azure AD > Security > Authentication methods > FIDO2 security key
technical_explanation.security_implications: Passwordless authentication eliminates password-based attack vectors and provides stronger security assurance through biometrics or hardware tokens.
technical_explanation.implementation_complexity: High - Requires device compatibility assessment, user training, and hardware procurement for FIDO2 keys.
technical_explanation.estimated_time_to_remediate: 3-6 months for full deployment including device assessment, hardware procurement, and user training
